payload_types.author: @its_a_feature_
payload_types.note:
This payload uses JavaScript for Automation (JXA) for execution on macOS boxes. 
There have been issues with macOS < 10.13 and encryption, so be sure to blank out the AESPSK and set key exchange to "F" when creating those payloads.

load_transforms.description: Combine all selected commands into one file

transforms.name: jsonSingleParameter
transforms.description: Takes a normal user string and converts it to a JSON string with one parameter

transforms.name: apfelljxa_test_password_shorthand
transforms.description: shorthand notation for apfell-jxa's test_command to allow a user to type "test_password user password"

transforms.name: apfelljxa_sleep_shorthand
transforms.description: Allow users to input sleep as "number number" for interval and jitter

transforms.name: combineCommands
transforms.description: This combines all of the selected commands together

commands.description: add a local user to the system by wrapping the Apple binary, dscl.

parameters.hint: password of the user that will execute the commands
parameters.name: passwd

parameters.hint: username that will execute the commands
parameters.name: user

commands.description:
Upload a file to the target machine by selecting a file from your computer or specifying a file_id. 
If you want to manually specify a "file_id" parameter, use the UUID associated with the file either from hosting it via the services or from another upload.

This uses JXA to execute the specified JavaScript code into a specific browser tab. The chrome_tabs function will specify for each tab the window/tab numbers that you can use for this function. Note: by default this ability is disabled in Chrome now, you will need to go to view->Developer->Allow JavaScript from Apple Events.
Use the built-in CGDisplay API calls to capture the display and send it back over the C2 channel. No need to specify any parameters as the current time will be used as the file name
Remove a file, no quotes are necessary and relative paths are fine
Create a custom prompt to ask the user for credentials where you can provide titles, icons, text and default answer. The buttons will be "OK" and "Cancel"

parameters.hint: Default answer to pre-populate (will show up as *****)
parameters.name: answer

parameters.hint: full path to .icns file to use
parameters.name: icon

commands.description: call a function from within the JS file that was imported with "jsimport". This function call is appended to the end of the jsimport code and called via eval.

commands.help_cmd: jsimport (then select the file to upload)
commands.description: import a JS file into memory. Only one can be imported at a time.
Spawn a new osascript download cradle  as a backgrounded process to launch a new callback
Generate a new payload, drop it to a temp location, execute it with osascript as a background process, and then delete the file. Automatically reports back the temp file it created
Read the contents of all open iTerm tabs if iTerms is open, otherwise just inform the operator that it's not currently running
Prints the current working directory for the agent
Get attributes about a file and display it to the user via API calls. No need for quotes and relative paths are fine
Change the current working directory to another directory. No quotes are necessary and relative paths are fine
Read the contents of a file and display it to the user. No need for quotes and relative paths are fine

commands.help_cmd: test_password with no args uses blank password and current user. or, test_password {"username": "bob", "password": "bob"}
commands.description: Tests a password against a user to see if it's valid via an API call

Create a launch agent or daemon plist file and either automatically put it in ~/Library/LaunchAgents or if LocalAgent is false, save it to the specified location. If you want an elevated launch agent or launch daemon( /Library/LaunchAgents or /Library/LaunchDaemons), you either need to be in an elevated context already and specify the path or use something like shell_elevated to copy it there. If the first arg is 'apfell-jxa' then Apfell will automatically construct a plist appropriate oneliner to use where arg1 should be the URL to reach out to for the payload.

parameters.hint: Path to save new plist to if LocalAgent is false
parameters.name: LaunchPath

artifacts.artifact_string: Potentially created "*" if we didn't create a launch agent file.

commands.description: Create persistence with an emond plist file in /etc/emond.d/rules/ and a .DS_Store file to trigger it

parameters.hint: Rule name for inside of the plist
parameters.name: rule_name

commands.help_cmd: read one file: plist {"type": "read", "filename": "full_path"}, read all plists of a certain type: plist {"type": ["readLaunchAgents" | "readLaunchDaemons"]}
commands.description: Read plists and their associated attributes for attempts to privilege escalate

parameters.hint: full filename path if type is just read
parameters.name: filename

commands.description: Gets the current running config via the C2 class
This uses JXA to get some system information. It doesn't send Apple Events to any other applications though, so it shouldn't cause popups.
Modify the time between callbacks in seconds.

The command will pop a dialog box for the user asking for them to authenticate (fingerprint reader too) so that the command you entered will be executed in an elevated context. Alternatively, you can supply a username and password and the command will run under their context (assuming they have the right permissions). Once you successfully authenticate, you have a time window where no more popups will occur, but you'll still execute subsequent commands in an elevated context.

WARNING! THIS IS SINGLE THREADED, IF YOUR COMMAND HANGS, THE AGENT HANGS!

parameters.hint: What prompt to display to the user when asking for permission
parameters.name: prompt

parameters.hint: Username that you want to run as
parameters.name: user

commands.description:
This uses JXA to read information about open instances of Apple's Terminal.app. The contents flag allows you to see exactly what the user can see at that moment on the screen. The history flag allows you to see everything that's in that tab's scroll history. This can be a lot of information, so keep that in mind. This function will also give you the window/tab information for each open session and a bunch of other information.
Ex: terminals_read history
This uses JXA to list some security information about the system by contacting the "System Events" application via Apple Events. This can cause a popup or be denied in Mojave and later

commands.help_cmd: From the GUI: run. From the cmd-line: run {"path":"/bin/ps","args":["-ax"]}
commands.description: The command uses the ObjectiveC bridge to spawn that process with those arguments on the computer and get your output back. It is not interactive and does not go through a shell, so be sure to specify the full path to the binary you want to run.

parameters.hint: Full path to binary to execute
parameters.name: path

commands.description: This uses JXA to list the non-service user accounts on the system. You can specify a GID to look at the users of a certain group or you can specify "groups" to be true and enumerate users by groups

This uses the Objective C bridge to launch the specified app asynchronously and 'hidden' (it'll still show up in the dock for now). An example of the bundle name is 'com.apple.itunes' for launching iTunes.

This runs the JavaScript command, {command}, and returns its output via an eval(). The output will get passed through ObjC.deepUnwrap to parse out basic data types from ObjectiveC and get strings back
Download a file from the victim machine to the apfell server in chunks (no need for quotes in the path). It will be saved to app/files/{operation name}/downloads/{hostname}/{filename}

attack.attack_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

commands.description: This will return the current clipboard contents on the target machine. If [data] is supplied, it will set the clipboard to [data].
This uses JXA to list information about the current user. In the future you can specify a [method] to do this via the ObjectiveC bridge or other methods. Right now this defaults to "api".

This loads a new function into memory via the C2 channel to be used by the operator. The code will be base64 encoded when requested. This will get transformed into load {"cmds": "cmd1, cmd2, cmd3", "file_id": #}
This exits the current apfell-jxa instance by leveraging the ObjectiveC bridge's NSApplication terminate function.

This uses JXA to inject the shell command, {command}, into the specified terminal shell as if the user typed it from the keyboard. This is pretty powerful. Consider the instance where the user is SSH-ed into another machine via terminal - with this you can inject commands to run on the remote host. Just remember, the user will be able to see the command, but you can always see what they see as well with the "terminals_read contents" command.

This uses JXA to list information about all of the bookmarks in Chrome. If Chrome is not currently running, this will launch Chrome (potential OPSEC issue) and might have a conflict with trying to access Chrome's bookmarks as Chrome is starting. It's recommended to not use this unless Chrome is already running. Use the list_apps function to check if Chrome is running.
In Mojave this will cause a popup the first time asking for permission for your process to access Chrome.

This uses JXA to list information about all of the open tabs in all of the open Chrome instances. If Chrome is not currently running, this will launch Chrome (potential OPSEC issue) and might have a conflict with trying to access Chrome tabs as Chrome is starting. It's recommended to not use this unless Chrome is already running. Use the list_apps function to check if Chrome is running.
In Mojave this will cause a popup the first time asking for permission for your process to access Chrome.
This uses NSApplication.RunningApplications api to get information about running applications.
Use Folder Actions to persist a compiled script on disk. You can either specify a 'URL' and automatically do a backgrounding one-liner, or supply your own code and language.

This runs {command} in a terminal by leveraging JXA's Application.doShellScript({command}).

WARNING! THIS IS SINGLE THREADED, IF YOUR COMMAND HANGS, THE AGENT HANGS!
